raw_text:
Aaliyah claim dismissed by court
 
 Late R&B star Aaliyah's record company has failed in an attempt to sue the video producer who booked the ill-fated flight on which she died in 2001.
 
 A New York appeals court has told Blackground Records that only the singer's parents had the right to launch a claim for wrongful death. The 22-year-old singer's family came to an undisclosed settlement over a negligence claim in 2003. Aaliyah had completed a music video when the plane crashed in the Bahamas. She and eight others were killed on the plane, which crashed as if left for Florida. Blackground Records' lawyer Frank Penski said he had yet to examine the decision and did not know whether they would pursue the case.
 
 An investigation into the crash revealed the twin-engined Cessna was overloaded by 700 pounds (320kg). A post-mortem carried out on the remains of the pilot showed there was cocaine and alcohol in his body. Aaliyah was a rising star in music and film before she was killed. She was honoured with a string of posthumous awards and her single More Than A Woman went to number one in the UK.

The case is over a negligence claim related to a post-mortem investigation into her death, which revealed cocaine and alcohol in the pilot's body.

Aaliyah was a successful artist before her tragic death.

Aaliyah was dismissed from the court due to being found wrongful dead in 2001. Her record company is suing the video producer of the plane crash where she died in 2001. An appeals court in New York ruled that only her parents have the right to claim for wrongful death, declining the case despite a negligence claim in 2003 that was not awarded damages. tinyllama:1.1b: Blackground Records failed to secure a wrongful death claim against the creator of a fatal flight that killed singer Aaliyah, an appeal court has ruled. Despite an undisclosed settlement over a negligence case, Aaliyah's family came to terms with the tragedy in 2003 and agreed to pay for a music video shot on the ill-fated aircraft. The singer had completed a music video before her plane crashed while en route from Florida to Jamaica. Her twin-engine propeller aircraft, carrying six passengers, was overloaded by 700 pounds (320kg), according to an investigation into the crash. There were no signs of alcohol or drugs in Aaliyah's body, and a post-mortem carried out on her remains revealed traces of cocktail drugs and alcohol. Despite the death of a rising star in music and film, Blackground Records claimed to have no right to launch a wrongful death claim over Aaliyah's tragic end.
tinydolphin:1.1b: A court has dismissed a claim made by Blackground Records, a record company, against the video producer responsible for booking the plane that tragically crashed in 2001, killing two passengers and leaving six others injured. The record company claimed they had a right to pursue a wrongful death suit on behalf of Aaliyah's family. However, New York's Court of Appeals recently ruled that only her parents could bring such a claim due to the settlement reached between them in 2003. Attorney Frank Penski has not commented publicly on the case but stated he would examine the court's decision and decide whether to pursue the claim or not.
